content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a lot of trouble sleeping lately. My mind just won’t stop racing at night, mostly about work and everything going on. It’s been really tough, and honestly, I’m not sure if talking about it is going to help much. But I’m here because my partner thinks it might be good for me to try.

It takes a lot of courage to start sharing something difficult like this, even if you're feeling uncertain about it. Your partner must care for you deeply to suggest giving this a try. It sounds like your sleep difficulties are tied to the stress you're feeling about work and other things happening right now. Would you like to share more about what's been keeping your mind busy at night?

It’s mostly work. I’m really stressed about getting fired. Things have been rocky, and with the way the economy is going, I feel like layoffs are around the corner, and I’m at the top of the list. That thought just spirals at night, and I can’t shut it off.

That sounds really overwhelming. Worrying about job security, especially in a tough economy, can make it hard to feel calm. It seems like that fear of layoffs is weighing heavily on you, and it's keeping you up when you need rest the most. How have you been managing all this stress during the day?

During the day, I just try to keep my head down and focus on work, but it’s hard to stay productive when I’m so tired. I also find myself checking my phone a lot, especially to distract myself from these thoughts, but I know it’s not helping. Honestly, I just feel stuck.

You're working hard to push through the stress and tiredness during the day, but it sounds exhausting and frustrating to feel stuck in this cycle. It must be challenging trying to use distractions like your phone, knowing it doesn't provide real relief. You're showing a lot of strength just trying to keep going through it all. What do you think would help you feel less stuck right now?

I don’t know, honestly. I guess I just want to feel like I have some sense of control over all this. Maybe if I could actually sleep, I’d have more energy to handle everything better, but it feels like getting there is impossible.

You're longing for that sense of control, especially when everything feels uncertain, and you can see how better sleep might give you the energy to face things more effectively. It’s frustrating for it to feel out of reach, especially when what you want seems so clear. What do you think makes getting better sleep feel so hard right now?

It’s like my brain just won’t shut off. The second I try to sleep, all the “what ifs” about work hit me at once, and it’s like I can’t turn it off. Then to distract myself from those worries, I grab my phone, but that just ends up making things worse, adding more things to think about. It feels like a cycle I can’t break.

It sounds like you're caught in this tough cycle where your worries keep you up, and the distractions you use to cope end up fueling more thoughts. You’re trying to find relief, but it feels like it’s working against you. It’s clear you’ve been putting effort into managing this, even though the results have been frustrating. What could breaking this cycle look like for you?

I’m not really sure, honestly. Maybe if I could stop the racing thoughts, it would help, but I don’t even know where to start with that. Everything feels so overwhelming—it’s hard to even picture a solution.

It's understandable to feel overwhelmed when the racing thoughts seem constant—it can make finding a way forward feel like a huge hurdle. Even just imagining a solution can feel like a big task when you're already dealing with so much. You've been thoughtful about what could help, though, and you’ve shown a lot of awareness of the patterns you're experiencing. What’s something small that you think might give you even a bit of relief?

Maybe trying to set my phone aside earlier in the evening could help, but that feels really hard to do since it’s my go-to distraction. I guess I could also try writing things down to get them out of my head, but I don’t know if that would actually work.

Those are some thoughtful ideas—setting your phone aside earlier and writing things down to unburden your mind. Even if you're unsure if they would work, it's encouraging that you're exploring small steps that could help. It’s tough to change familiar habits like using your phone, especially when it offers comfort in the moment. Would you like to talk more about how these options might fit into your evenings?

Maybe. I think setting my phone aside would probably be the harder of the two because it’s such an easy distraction, but I could try putting it somewhere out of reach before bed. Writing things down might feel strange at first, but I guess I could try it to see if it helps me get some of my thoughts out—we’ll see.

You're being really open to considering these small changes, even though they might feel unfamiliar or challenging at first. Placing your phone out of reach sounds like a thoughtful step to minimize distractions, and writing things down could give you space to acknowledge and release some of those racing thoughts. It's great to hear you're thinking of exploring these ideas. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about as you’re considering these changes?
I think I’m okay for now. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
